body_text.section: Robust cell cycle exit mechanisms

body_text.text: In contrast, cells with high CycE-Cdk2 after differentiation fail to complete their final G1-S transition or arrest in S phase with low E2F1 protein levels , suggesting that the E2F1 degradation machinery remains active.
body_text.section: Robust cell cycle exit mechanisms

body_text.text: This arrest may be partially caused by the depletion of E2F target genes critical for S-phase completion.
body_text.section: Robust cell cycle exit mechanisms

body_text.text: But the arrest of rbf / cells overexpressing CycE in the wing blade, which have high levels of E2F target gene expression from previous cell cycles, suggests that there may also be an activation of a checkpoint or inhibition of a key activity for S-phase completion independent of E2F transcriptional regulation after terminal differentiation.
body_text.section: Robust cell cycle exit mechanisms

body_text.text: Although we do not know the specific mechanism for this arrest, the addition of Stg is able to restore cycling in rbf / cells overexpressing CycE (Fig. 3 and Table I).
body_text.section: Robust cell cycle exit mechanisms

body_text.text: This demonstrates that Stg or a target of Cdk1 activity is able to bypass the arrest of cells with high CycE-Cdk2 after terminal differentiation to allow E2F1 reaccumulation.
body_text.section: Robust cell cycle exit mechanisms

body_text.text: Importantly, the cell cycle control mechanisms we describe in this study do not act alone at exit.
body_text.section: Robust cell cycle exit mechanisms

body_text.text: They likely cooperate with other cell cycle inhibitors known to promote exit such as Dacapo, Fbw7, and Hippo signaling.
body_text.section: Robust cell cycle exit mechanisms

body_text.text: These cell cycle controls together limit cell cycle reentry to ensure robust cell cycle exit upon terminal differentiation.
body_text.section: Robust cell cycle exit mechanisms

body_text.text: The data presented in this study demonstrate an important role for the APC/C in maintaining cell cycle exit in the face of aberrant E2F activity in terminally differentiated postmitotic tissues (Fig. 5).
body_text.section: APC/C functions in terminally differentiated cells

body_text.text: Interestingly, work in mammalian neurons has shown additional postmitotic functions for the APC/C in mature cells (Puram et al., 2010).
body_text.section: APC/C functions in terminally differentiated cells

body_text.text: Both the APC/C Fzr/Cdh1 and APC/C Cdc20 complexes carry out important nonmitotic functions in the control of axon and dendrite growth and patterning, synapse development, and neuron survival (Konishi et al., 2004;Li et al., 2008;Huynh et al., 2009;Kim et al., 2009;Yang et al., 2009).
body_text.section: APC/C functions in terminally differentiated cells

body_text.text: This suggests that the APC/C complexes in many terminally differentiated cells carry out previously unappreciated dual roles in promoting postmitotic cell maturation and protecting against aberrant cell cycle reentry.
body_text.section: APC/C functions in terminally differentiated cells

body_text.text: This is supported by the recent finding that Cdh1 is a haplo-insufficient tumor suppressor in mice (García-Higuera et al., 2008), although further studies will be required to determine whether the tumors in Cdh1 APC/C Fzr activity normally increases at G1 arrest, degrading G2 and mitotic cell cycle targets such as CycA, CycB, and Stg ( Fig. S2; Sigrist and Lehner, 1997;Pimentel and Venkatesh, 2005;Tanaka-Matakatsu et al., 2007;Zielke, 2007).
body_text.section: APC/C functions in terminally differentiated cells

body_text.text: This function of the APC/C is essential for timely exit, as loss of the APC/C is sufficient to cause an additional cell cycle, likely via unrestrained CycA activity (Table I;  Sigrist and Lehner, 1997;Jacobs et al., 2001;Tanaka-Matakatsu et al., 2007).
body_text.section: APC/C functions in terminally differentiated cells

body_text.text: The mammalian APC/C Fzr/Cdh1 has been shown to interact with RB to promote cell cycle exit via degradation of Skp2 and subsequent stabilization of p27 Kip1 (Binné et al., 2007).
body_text.section: APC/C functions in terminally differentiated cells

body_text.text: A similar mechanism may also act to promote exit in Drosophila via APC/C Fzr , Rbf, and Dacapo, but functions for a Drosophila Skp2 homologue in cell cycle control have not yet been examined.
body_text.section: APC/C functions in terminally differentiated cells

body_text.text: When E2F is aberrantly activated in differentiating cells, expression of several APC/C Fzy components increases and may cooperate with high APC/C Fzr to limit the accumulation of mitotic cyclins and other essential E2F transcriptional targets for cycling such as Stg (Figs. 5 and 6).
body_text.section: APC/C functions in terminally differentiated cells

body_text.text: CycE-Cdk2 activity has been shown to inhibit APC/C (Sigrist and Lehner, 1997;Reber et al., 2006), and thus, the increased APC/C activity present in differentiating cells may raise the threshold levels of CycE required for APC/C suppression.
body_text.section: APC/C functions in terminally differentiated cells

body_text.text: Our data suggest that this may explain, at least in part, why supraphysiological levels of ectopic CycE are required to bypass cell cycle exit in differentiating wings and eyes (Fig. 7).
body_text.section: APC/C functions in terminally differentiated cells

body_text.text: If CycE-Cdk2 is aberrantly activated in differentiating cells, cell cycle exit is temporarily delayed with cells arresting at the G1-S transition or in early S phase with phosphorylated histone locus bodies and some partially replicated DNA .
body_text.section: APC/C functions in terminally differentiated cells

body_text.text: In such cells, the S phase-dependent degradation of E2F1 protein by the Cul4 ubiquitin E3 ligase appears to remain on, leading to an increased ratio of repressive E2F2 to E2F1.
body_text.section: APC/C functions in terminally differentiated cells

body_text.text: This ultimately results in stable CycE-Cdk2-resistant repression of E2F target genes and cell cycle exit (Fig. 1).
body_text.section: APC/C functions in terminally differentiated cells

body_text.text: If E2F2 is absent, aberrant CycE-Cdk2 leads to S-phase initiation and PIP boxdependent Cul4-mediated destruction of E2F1, resulting in loss of both E2Fs and thereby loss of all E2F-DP function.
body_text.section: APC/C functions in terminally differentiated cells

body_text.text: This situation is similar to that in Dp mutants, which lack all E2F-dependent transcriptional function.
body_text.section: APC/C functions in terminally differentiated cells

body_text.text: In these mutants, critical cell cycle genes, including Stg and other cyclin-Cdk regulators, are protected from derepression (Fig. 4 B), and their expression remains low, ensuring a noncycling state.

body_text.text: It is becoming increasingly clear that certain highly differentiated cells retain the ability to enter the cell cycle.
body_text.section: Cell cycle exit, terminal differentiation, and cancer

body_text.text: In some cases, this serves a beneficial regenerative function, as recently shown for terminally differentiated cardiomyocytes in the zebrafish heart (Jopling et al., 2010;Kikuchi et al., 2010).
body_text.section: Cell cycle exit, terminal differentiation, and cancer

body_text.text: But in other cases, this ability seems to be a part of the normal tissue development, as shown for differentiated horizontal cells that reenter the cell cycle for their final division in the zebrafish retina before full maturation (Godinho et al., 2007).
body_text.section: Cell cycle exit, terminal differentiation, and cancer

body_text.text: Proliferation of terminally differentiated mammalian cells has also been observed in monocytes and macrophages lacking the c-Maf and MafB transcription factors (Aziz et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Cell cycle exit, terminal differentiation, and cancer

body_text.text: Strikingly, Maf double knockout macrophages appear to fully retain their differentiation-associated functions in vivo despite exhibiting continued cycling for months, demonstrating a clear independence of differentiation and cell cycle exit in these cells (Aziz et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Cell cycle exit, terminal differentiation, and cancer

body_text.text: We have shown that cell cycle exit is not essential for terminal differentiation in Drosophila eyes and wings.
body_text.section: Cell cycle exit, terminal differentiation, and cancer

body_text.text: Evasion of the robust cell cycle exit mechanism by loss of the tumor suppressor rbf together with deregulation of CycE and Stg can lead to tumor-like overproliferation of differentiated tissues (Fig. 3).
body_text.section: Cell cycle exit, terminal differentiation, and cancer

body_text.text: Our results may be relevant to specific cancers such as retinoblastoma, where aberrantly dividing differentiated cells have been proposed to be the cancer cell of origin (Chen et al., 2004;Ajioka et al., 2007;Xu et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Cell cycle exit, terminal differentiation, and cancer

body_text.text: Aberrant division of differentiated cells could lead to genetic instability and acquisition of secondary mutations, leading to dedifferentiation and ultimately to metastatic cancer.
body_text.section: Cell cycle exit, terminal differentiation, and cancer

body_text.text: Our data show that the robust exit mechanism is essential for proper tissue development and suggest that even terminally differentiated cells should not be excluded as a potential source of cancer.

body_text.text: Because E2F1-DP is thought to act as a transcriptional activator, this group of repressed genes is somewhat unexpected.
body_text.section: Fly strains

body_text.text: These genes are not repressed indirectly by a delay in cell cycle exit, as they are similarly repressed in Dp mutants, which exit normally.
body_text.section: Fly strains

body_text.text: We also do not believe that this group is caused by E2F1-DP repressive complexes blocking transcription, as such targets would be expected to increase rather than decrease in Dp mutants.
body_text.section: Fly strains

body_text.text: One possibility suggested by Bracken et al. (2004) is that the extensive transcriptional up-regulation caused by E2F (or in Dp mutants) could cause some spurious antisense regulation of genes.
body_text.section: Fly strains

body_text.text: Although we have not investigated this possibility, >0% of the transcriptional changes we observed in both genotypes are indeed increases in transcript levels.
body_text.section: Fly strains

body_text.text: Overall, this group of repressed transcripts is significantly enriched for genes involved in monooxygenase activity (caused by six cytochromeP450 genes; P < 8.08 4 ) and genes with catalytic activity (P < 5.85 4 ), suggesting some functional significance for this group.

body_text.text: We were surprised to find that most transcripts were not affected by E2F overexpression or Dp loss at the proliferative L3 time point.

body_text.text: This may be because E2F target gene expression is already high in controls during proliferation, as evident by the high activity of the E2F reporter construct (PCNA-GFP) and high levels of E2F target gene expression at this stage (Thacker et al., 2003).

body_text.text: This is also supported by our finding that the few transcripts up-regulated by E2F and/or Dp loss at L3 are normally at low abundance in wings and were significantly (P < 0.009) enriched for genes with expression one standard deviation lower than the mean gene expression.

body_text.text: Thus, the transcriptional activation of E2F targets at proliferative stages seems to be masked by the high levels of E2F activity already present in the controls.

body_text.text: Interestingly, this also suggests that normal levels of E2F targets are somehow maintained in an E2F-DP-independent manner in proliferating Dp mutant cells.
